full_text: Let's look at the behaviors of contact data synchronization from the account to the policy. Amy Taylor called to get a personal auto policy for her car. Create a new person account for Amy with a home phone number. Create a new submission for personal auto. Go to the policy info page. Click the primary named insured link. Amy Taylor's information is the same as the account because new submission always copies the contact data from the account. Complete other steps like driver and vehicles. Quote and issue the policy. After two months, Amy called to inform that she had gotten married and would like to change her last name to King. Go to the account. Go to the account contacts page. Edit the contact. Change the contact's last name. She also has a new phone number. Save the changes. Open the previous policy. Go to the policy contacts page. The contact name is a revision field. So it is not synchronized from the account to the policy because it has been bound. The phone number on the policy, however, shows the same value as account since it is a shared field. The reason the name is revisioned and the phone number is not is because the name is part of the policy contract data, whereas the phone number is not, and they are configured accordingly. After three months, Amy called to renew the policy for six months. In the policy, click actions. Select renew policy. Go to the policy. Go to the policy info page. The name on the renewal job is the same as the account. To summarize, the shared data of a contact is always the same on both the account and the policy. If a revision contact field is changed on the account, it will not be synchronized to the bound policies. So that each policy can keep the history of contact data. New policy jobs copy the current contact data from the account, with the exception of a backdated policy change job, which keeps the original policy data. This is the end of demonstration for contact data synchronization from account to policy.

segments.text: Let's look at the behaviors of contact data synchronization from the account to the policy. Amy Taylor called to get a personal auto policy for her car. Create a new person account for Amy with a home phone number. Create a new submission for personal auto. Go to the policy info page. Click the primary named insured link.

Amy Taylor's information is the same as the account because new submission always copies the contact data from the account. Complete other steps like driver and vehicles. Quote and issue the policy. After two months, Amy called to inform that she had gotten married and would like to change her last name to King. Go to the account. Go to the account contacts page. Edit the contact.
Change the contact's last name. She also has a new phone number. Save the changes. Open the previous policy. Go to the policy contacts page. The contact name is a revision field.

So it is not synchronized from the account to the policy because it has been bound. The phone number on the policy, however, shows the same value as account since it is a shared field. The reason the name is revisioned and the phone number is not is because the name is part of the policy contract data, whereas the phone number is not, and they are configured accordingly. After three months, Amy called to renew the policy for six months. In the policy, click actions. Select renew policy.
Go to the policy. Go to the policy info page.
The name on the renewal job is the same as the account.

To summarize, the shared data of a contact is always the same on both the account and the policy. If a revision contact field is changed on the account, it will not be synchronized to the bound policies.

So that each policy can keep the history of contact data. New policy jobs copy the current contact data from the account, with the exception of a backdated policy change job, which keeps the original policy data. This is the end of demonstration for contact data synchronization from account to policy.
